div.head: A.1. Paired posterior distributions from a full model with a free-to-vary diffusion coefficient
div.p: In Figures 8, 9, 10, and 11, we show samples from paired posterior draws of Model dcDDM for multiple pairs of parameters. For each simulation, a parameter set was drawn randomly from the priors. After model fitting, the shape of the joint posteriors depends on the data. The mean and standard deviation of the number of simulated trials were 179 ± 73. Each subplot within a figure corresponds to a different simulation. The same location of the subplots across the four figures shows a different projection of the joint posterior distribution from the same simulation.

Not all paired posterior distributions that include the non-decision time and start-point parameters are plotted. Those parameters are recovered in each simulation (see the last two columns of Figure 7) and the resulting plotted posterior samples for each simulation were usually circular clouds of dots, indicating approximately multivariate normal posterior distributions with little correlation between the paired parameters.

div.head: A.2. Paired posterior distributions from a model with participant-level covariates
div.p: Figures 12, 13, and 14 include samples from paired posterior draws of Model dcDDM-that describes external covariates by participant-level boundary parameters when the measurement noise of external covariates was = 0.1 (see Figures 6 and 5b). The parameters for the posteriors from the first simulated participant are described in the text of Section 3.4 and Figure 5. For the rest of the simulated participants, the DDM parameters were drawn randomly from the following distributions:

A.3. Joint posterior distributions from a model with trial-level covariates Figures 15, 16 and 17 include samples from paired posterior draws of Model dcDDM-that describes singletrial external covariates through trial-to-trial boundary changes in addition to choice-RTs. A parameter set was drawn randomly from the priors for each simulation. A subset of 18 of these simulations were found with proportions of cognitive variance > 0.90 in the external covariate. The mean and standard deviation of the number of simulated trials were 181 ± 69 in these 18 simulations. Each subplot within a figure corresponds to a different simulation. The same location of the subplots across the four figures shows a different projection of the joint posterior distribution from the same simulation. Figure 18 shows a joint posterior of three parameters for one representative simulation to compare to Figure 4. Figure 19a shows parameter recovery of the proportion of external covariate variance explained by cognition for 500 simulations of Model dcDDM-. Figure 19b shows parameter recovery of the same model when the model was misspecified, specifically when simulating from Model dcDDM-with 1 = 2. Further details are given in Section 3.6 of the main text.

div.head: B. Fitting DDMs to trial-level EEG and behavioral data B.1. Fitting DDMs to real EEG and behavioral data
div.p: We sought to further verify the usefulness of fitting model dcDDM-by fitting the model to real data. Mattes et al. (2022) found evidence that a single-trial EEG measure, thought to reflect response monitoring after an experimental trial (the error/correct positivity Pe/c), was negatively associated with single-trial boundaries on the subsequent trials of an Eriksen flanker task (Eriksen and Eriksen, 1974). They evaluated fits of DDMs with fixed diffusion coefficients to the data using the HDDM package by Wiecki et al. (2013). The original data is from a paper by Stahl et al. (2015), and the extracted single-trial measures were provided on the Open Science Framework (OSF) at https://osf.io/8nbd4/. However, we should note here that this data and model combination was not going to be useful to measure individual differences in an ideal scenario of high correlation of single-trial Pe/c to single-trial boundaries . This is because the mean was subtracted from the original Pe/c before preprocessing (Mattes et al., 2022), effectively removing the variance across individuals. We use this data set instead as an example for obtaining parameter estimates from Model dcDDM-.

We thought this dataset would be a good candidate to attempt to measure all three evidence parameters with dcDDM-within participants. This was based on the results shown by Mattes et al. (2022) in their DDM model fits. Specifically, the authors fit an embedded-regression models using single-trial Pe/c and Ne/c -a post-decision negative
